Article: Chinaâs big AI plan â to dominate the global market with its AI technology by 2030 â is widely known and deeply feared in the rest of the world. The lingering mystery, though, is how much of the best-laid plans of China will come to pass, if ever. Chinaâs State Council proposed in July 2017 âA Next-Generation Artificial Intelligence Development Plan.â It says that China will ultimately become the world leader in artificial intelligence, with a domestic AI industry worth almost $150 billion by 2030. The first step is to catch up with the United States on AI technology and applications by 2020. Itâs easy to call this mere bravado, but itâs probably not wise. As I see it, the Chinese genie is already out of the bottle. Beijingâs ânational championâ technology leaders â Baidu, Alibaba, Tencent, and iFlyTek â are established, successful firms. They are leading the development of innovation platforms such as self-driving cars, smart cities, computer vision for medical diagnosis, and voice intelligence. The newest ânational championâ listed by Beijing is the Hong Kong startup SenseTime, which specializes in face- and image-recognition technology. Veteran reporters on the global IC beat remember a series of âfive-year plansâ launched by the Chinese government a few decades ago, explicitly intended to kickstart an indigenous semiconductor industry. These early efforts resulted in the establishment of SMIC but not much else. Then in the 2010s, a host of Chinese chip startups sprang up, each designing its own SoCs with licensable cores from companies such as Arm and Ceva. To date, the Middle Kingdom, however, hasnât exactly cracked the global chip market, although China is now making an even bigger investment fund available for the domestic chip industry. Chinaâs AI plan and its big fund for the IC industry share common threads that include the governmentâs huge budgets, aspirations, and ego. But the AI plan is likely to follow a path of its own because China already has established AI giants. Furthermore, the South China Morning Post, owned by Alibaba, claims that China now dominates AI funding. Last year, 48% of total equity funding of AI startups globally came from China, compared to a U.S. outlay of 38% and 13% by the rest of the world. This is a significant jump from Chinaâs 11.3% in 2016. The most convincing indication of Chinaâs rise in the AI market that I recently came across was the plethora of AI-driven toys displayed, demonstrated, and pitched at shop after shop in the Shenzhen airport. The toys range from battery-operated âsmartâ dogs and dancing programmable robots to conversational C3POs and interactive AI âeducationalâ robots with a remote âbabysittingâ mode that takes snapshots of the kids and transmits them to Mom and Dad. AI-driven toy robots (Photo: EE Times)  You may laugh. After all, weâre only talking about toys whose AI capabilities are primitive. I laughed, too, until it dawned on me that Chinaâs booming toy business is the rare â possibly exclusive â example of making real money with AI. Chinaâs âeducationalâ robots come with a level of intelligence equivalent to that of low-end smartphones. But itâs presumptuous to judge these so-called AI-driven consumer goods as just toys. An interactive chatty robot with an AI system equipped with a range of English-language learning materials is a cheap shortcut to fluency for Chinese parents who want their kids to grow up and speak English. Even a robot whose conversation might seem a little dumb to a grownup doesnât bother kids as long as the robots respond to them in an animated, interactive fashion.
